--
+The `get-*` tools that we've built are already super useful and budding spellcasters will be glad to have help in perfecting their concoctions and learning ancient incantations. However, where the power of AI agents really starts to shine is when they go beyond just reading data and start taking actions. Let's give AI the ability to cast spells. ðŸª„
+
+We'll register another tool in `apps/mcp-server/src/main.ts`
+
+```ts {% fileName="apps/mcp-server/src/main.ts" %}
+import { z } from 'zod';
+
+// ... previous tools
+
+server.tool(
+  'cast-spell',
--
+```
+
+There are two key differences in this tool definition:
+
+- We've passed a description string as the second argument. You can do this for every tool in order to describe what to use it for and what will happen when the agent calls it. `cast-spell` is sort of self-explanatory but it's still good practice to add a description and increase the model's chances of picking the right tool for the job. You can even add more annotations to mark a tool as read-only, destructive or more.
+- We've passed an object that defines the shape of the input using [`zod`](https://zod.dev/). This lets the agent know how to structure the inputs that are passed to the tool. `ingredients` and `incantations` as arrays of strings aren't very complicated, but you could also add descriptions to each individual option to explain what it does. The full feature set of `zod` is available to define exactly what's possible with each tool.
+
+Now, let's try it out in an actual agent. I'll use VSCode & GitHub Copilot for this but any agent implementation with MCP support will do. I really like [Windsurf](https://docs.windsurf.com/windsurf/getting-started) or [Cursor](https://www.cursor.com/), for example.
+
+Register the MCP server by editing `.vscode/mcp.json` (or using the built-in command):

--
+The `get-*` tools that we've built are already super useful and budding spellcasters will be glad to have help in perfecting their concoctions and learning ancient incantations. However, where the power of AI agents really starts to shine is when they go beyond just reading data and start taking actions. Let's give AI the ability to cast spells. ðŸª„
+
+We'll register another tool in `apps/mcp-server/src/main.ts`
+
+```ts {% fileName="apps/mcp-server/src/main.ts" %}
+import { z } from 'zod';
+
+// ... previous tools
+
+server.tool(
+  'cast-spell',
--
+```
+
+There are two key differences in this tool definition:
+
+- We've passed a description string as the second argument. You can do this for every tool in order to describe what to use it for and what will happen when the agent calls it. `cast-spell` is sort of self-explanatory but it's still good practice to add a description and increase the model's chances of picking the right tool for the job. You can even add more annotations to mark a tool as read-only, destructive or more.
+- We've passed an object that defines the shape of the input using [`zod`](https://zod.dev/). This lets the agent know how to structure the inputs that are passed to the tool. `ingredients` and `incantations` as arrays of strings aren't very complicated, but you could also add descriptions to each individual option to explain what it does. The full feature set of `zod` is available to define exactly what's possible with each tool.
+
+Now, let's try it out in an actual agent. I'll use VSCode & GitHub Copilot for this but any agent implementation with MCP support will do. I really like [Windsurf](https://docs.windsurf.com/windsurf/getting-started) or [Cursor](https://www.cursor.com/), for example.
+
+Register the MCP server by editing `.vscode/mcp.json` (or using the built-in command):

{
  "name": "@nx/nx-source",
  "description": "Smart Repos Â· Fast Builds",
  "homepage": "https://nx.dev",
  "private": true,
  "scripts": {
    "build": "nx run-many --target build --parallel 8 --exclude nx-dev,typedoc-theme,tools-documentation-create-embeddings,nx-dev-util-ai",
    "commit": "czg",
    "check-commit": "node ./scripts/commit-lint.js",
    "check-format": "nx format:check --all",
    "check-format:quick": "pretty-quick --check",
    "check-imports": "node ./scripts/check-imports.js",
    "check-lock-files": "node ./scripts/check-lock-files.js",
    "check-documentation-map": "ts-node -P ./scripts/tsconfig.scripts.json ./scripts/documentation/map-link-checker.ts",
    "check-codeowners": "ts-node -P ./scripts/tsconfig.scripts.json ./scripts/check-codeowners.ts",
    "nx-release": "nx nx-release @nx/nx-source --parallel 8",
    "prepublishOnly": "node ./scripts/update-package-group.js",
    "local-registry": "nx local-registry @nx/nx-source",
    "documentation": "nx documentation",
    "submit-plugin": "node ./scripts/submit-plugin.js",
    "prepare": "is-ci || husky",
    "echo": "echo 123458",
    "preinstall": "node ./scripts/preinstall.js",
    "test": "nx run-many -t test",

{
  "name": "nx",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "private": false,
  "description": "The core Nx plugin contains the core functionality of Nx like the project graph, nx commands and task orchestration.",
  "repository": {
    "type": "git",
    "url": "https://github.com/nrwl/nx.git",
    "directory": "packages/nx"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "postinstall": "node ./bin/post-install"
  },
  "keywords": [
    "Monorepo",
    "Angular",
    "React",
    "Web",
    "Node",
    "Nest",
    "Jest",
    "Cypress",
    "CLI",
    "Testing",
    "Front-end",
    "Backend",
    "Mobile"
  ],
  "bin": {
    "nx": "./bin/nx.js",
    "nx-cloud": "./bin/nx-cloud.js"
  },
  "author": "Victor Savkin",
  "license": "MIT",
  "bugs": {
    "url": "https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues"
  },
  "homepage": "https://nx.dev",
  "dependencies": {
    "@napi-rs/wasm-runtime": "0.2.4",
    "@yarnpkg/lockfile": "^1.1.0",
    "@yarnpkg/parsers": "3.0.2",
    "@zkochan/js-yaml": "0.0.7",
    "axios": "^1.8.3",
    "chalk": "^4.1.0",
    "cli-cursor": "3.1.0",
    "cli-spinners": "2.6.1",
    "cliui": "^8.0.1",
    "dotenv": "~16.4.5",
    "dotenv-expand": "~11.0.6",
    "enquirer": "~2.3.6",
    "figures": "3.2.0",
    "flat": "^5.0.2",
    "front-matter": "^4.0.2",
    "ignore": "^5.0.4",
    "jest-diff": "^29.4.1",
    "jsonc-parser": "3.2.0",
    "lines-and-columns": "2.0.3",
    "minimatch": "9.0.3",
    "node-machine-id": "1.1.12",
    "npm-run-path": "^4.0.1",
    "open": "^8.4.0",
    "ora": "5.3.0",
    "resolve.exports": "2.0.3",
    "semver": "^7.5.3",
    "string-width": "^4.2.3",
    "tar-stream": "~2.2.0",
    "tmp": "~0.2.1",
    "tree-kill": "^1.2.2",
    "tsconfig-paths": "^4.1.2",
    "tslib": "^2.3.0",
    "yaml": "^2.6.0",
    "yargs": "^17.6.2",
    "yargs-parser": "21.1.1"
  },
  "peerDependencies": {
    "@swc-node/register": "^1.8.0",
    "@swc/core": "^1.3.85"
  },
  "peerDependenciesMeta": {
    "@swc-node/register": {
      "optional": true
    },
    "@swc/core": {
      "optional": true
    }
  },
  "optionalDependencies": {
    "@nx/nx-darwin-arm64": "*",
    "@nx/nx-darwin-x64": "*",
    "@nx/nx-freebsd-x64": "*",
    "@nx/nx-linux-arm-gnueabihf": "*",
    "@nx/nx-linux-arm64-gnu": "*",
    "@nx/nx-linux-arm64-musl": "*",
    "@nx/nx-linux-x64-gnu": "*",
    "@nx/nx-linux-x64-musl": "*",
    "@nx/nx-win32-arm64-msvc": "*",
    "@nx/nx-win32-x64-msvc": "*"
  },
  "nx-migrations": {
    "migrations": "./migrations.json",
    "packageGroup": [
      "@nx/js",
      "@nx/jest",
      "@nx/linter",
      "@nx/eslint",
      "@nx/workspace",
      "@nx/angular",
      "@nx/cypress",
      "@nx/detox",
      "@nx/devkit",
      "@nx/esbuild",
      "@nx/eslint-plugin",
      "@nx/expo",
      "@nx/express",
      "@nx/gradle",
      "@nx/module-federation",
      "@nx/nest",
      "@nx/next",
      "@nx/node",
      "@nx/nuxt",
      "@nx/playwright",
      "@nx/plugin",
      "@nx/react",
      "@nx/react-native",
      "@nx/rollup",
      "@nx/remix",
      "@nx/rspack",
      "@nx/rsbuild",
      "@nx/storybook",
      "@nx/vite",
      "@nx/vue",
      "@nx/web",
      "@nx/webpack",
      {
        "package": "nx-cloud",
        "version": "latest"
      },
      {
        "package": "@nrwl/nx-cloud",
        "version": "latest"
      }
    ]
  },
  "generators": "./generators.json",
  "executors": "./executors.json",
  "builders": "./executors.json",
  "publishConfig": {
    "access": "public"
  },
  "napi": {
    "binaryName": "nx",
    "packageName": "@nx/nx",
    "wasm": {
      "initialMemory": 1024,
      "maximumMemory": 32768
    },
    "targets": [
      "x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu",
      "x86_64-pc-windows-msvc",
      "x86_64-apple-darwin",
      "aarch64-apple-darwin",
      "aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu",
      "aarch64-unknown-linux-musl",
      "aarch64-pc-windows-msvc",
      "armv7-unknown-linux-gnueabihf",
      "x86_64-unknown-linux-musl",
      "x86_64-unknown-freebsd"
    ]
  }
}

{
  "name": "nx",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "private": false,
  "description": "The core Nx plugin contains the core functionality of Nx like the project graph, nx commands and task orchestration.",
  "repository": {
    "type": "git",
    "url": "https://github.com/nrwl/nx.git",
    "directory": "packages/nx"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "postinstall": "node ./bin/post-install"
  },
  "keywords": [
    "Monorepo",
    "Angular",
    "React",
    "Web",
    "Node",
    "Nest",
    "Jest",
    "Cypress",
    "CLI",
    "Testing",
    "Front-end",
    "Backend",
    "Mobile"
  ],
  "bin": {
    "nx": "./bin/nx.js",
    "nx-cloud": "./bin/nx-cloud.js"
  },
  "author": "Victor Savkin",
  "license": "MIT",
  "bugs": {
    "url": "https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues"
  },
  "homepage": "https://nx.dev",
  "dependencies": {
    "@napi-rs/wasm-runtime": "0.2.4",
    "@yarnpkg/lockfile": "^1.1.0",
    "@yarnpkg/parsers": "3.0.2",
    "@zkochan/js-yaml": "0.0.7",
    "axios": "^1.8.3",
    "chalk": "^4.1.0",
    "cli-cursor": "3.1.0",
    "cli-spinners": "2.6.1",
    "cliui": "^8.0.1",
    "dotenv": "~16.4.5",
    "dotenv-expand": "~11.0.6",
    "enquirer": "~2.3.6",
    "figures": "3.2.0",
    "flat": "^5.0.2",
    "front-matter": "^4.0.2",
    "ignore": "^5.0.4",
    "jest-diff": "^29.4.1",
    "jsonc-parser": "3.2.0",
    "lines-and-columns": "2.0.3",
    "minimatch": "9.0.3",
    "node-machine-id": "1.1.12",
    "npm-run-path": "^4.0.1",
    "open": "^8.4.0",
    "ora": "5.3.0",
    "resolve.exports": "2.0.3",
    "semver": "^7.5.3",
    "string-width": "^4.2.3",
    "tar-stream": "~2.2.0",
    "tmp": "~0.2.1",
    "tree-kill": "^1.2.2",
    "tsconfig-paths": "^4.1.2",
    "tslib": "^2.3.0",
    "yaml": "^2.6.0",
    "yargs": "^17.6.2",
    "yargs-parser": "21.1.1"
  },
  "peerDependencies": {
    "@swc-node/register": "^1.8.0",
    "@swc/core": "^1.3.85"
  },
  "peerDependenciesMeta": {
    "@swc-node/register": {
      "optional": true
    },
    "@swc/core": {
      "optional": true
    }
  },
  "optionalDependencies": {
    "@nx/nx-darwin-arm64": "*",
    "@nx/nx-darwin-x64": "*",
    "@nx/nx-freebsd-x64": "*",
    "@nx/nx-linux-arm-gnueabihf": "*",
    "@nx/nx-linux-arm64-gnu": "*",
    "@nx/nx-linux-arm64-musl": "*",
    "@nx/nx-linux-x64-gnu": "*",
    "@nx/nx-linux-x64-musl": "*",
    "@nx/nx-win32-arm64-msvc": "*",
    "@nx/nx-win32-x64-msvc": "*"
  },
  "nx-migrations": {
    "migrations": "./migrations.json",
    "packageGroup": [
      "@nx/js",
      "@nx/jest",
      "@nx/linter",
      "@nx/eslint",
      "@nx/workspace",
      "@nx/angular",
      "@nx/cypress",
      "@nx/detox",
      "@nx/devkit",
      "@nx/esbuild",
      "@nx/eslint-plugin",
      "@nx/expo",
      "@nx/express",
      "@nx/gradle",
      "@nx/module-federation",
      "@nx/nest",
      "@nx/next",
      "@nx/node",
      "@nx/nuxt",
      "@nx/playwright",
      "@nx/plugin",
      "@nx/react",
      "@nx/react-native",
      "@nx/rollup",
      "@nx/remix",
      "@nx/rspack",
      "@nx/rsbuild",
      "@nx/storybook",
      "@nx/vite",
      "@nx/vue",
      "@nx/web",
      "@nx/webpack",
      {
        "package": "nx-cloud",
        "version": "latest"
      },
      {
        "package": "@nrwl/nx-cloud",
        "version": "latest"
      }
    ]
  },
  "generators": "./generators.json",
  "executors": "./executors.json",
  "builders": "./executors.json",
  "publishConfig": {
    "access": "public"
  },
  "napi": {
    "binaryName": "nx",
    "packageName": "@nx/nx",
    "wasm": {
      "initialMemory": 1024,
      "maximumMemory": 32768
    },
    "targets": [
      "x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu",
      "x86_64-pc-windows-msvc",
      "x86_64-apple-darwin",
      "aarch64-apple-darwin",
      "aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu",
      "aarch64-unknown-linux-musl",
      "aarch64-pc-windows-msvc",
      "armv7-unknown-linux-gnueabihf",
      "x86_64-unknown-linux-musl",
      "x86_64-unknown-freebsd"
    ]
  }
}

{
  "name": "@nx/nx-source",
  "description": "Smart Repos Â· Fast Builds",
  "homepage": "https://nx.dev",
  "private": true,
  "scripts": {
    "build": "nx run-many --target build --parallel 8 --exclude nx-dev,typedoc-theme,tools-documentation-create-embeddings,nx-dev-util-ai",
    "commit": "czg",
    "check-commit": "node ./scripts/commit-lint.js",
    "check-format": "nx format:check --all",
    "check-format:quick": "pretty-quick --check",
    "check-imports": "node ./scripts/check-imports.js",
    "check-lock-files": "node ./scripts/check-lock-files.js",
    "check-documentation-map": "ts-node -P ./scripts/tsconfig.scripts.json ./scripts/documentation/map-link-checker.ts",
    "check-codeowners": "ts-node -P ./scripts/tsconfig.scripts.json ./scripts/check-codeowners.ts",
    "nx-release": "nx nx-release @nx/nx-source --parallel 8",
    "prepublishOnly": "node ./scripts/update-package-group.js",
    "local-registry": "nx local-registry @nx/nx-source",
    "documentation": "nx documentation",
    "submit-plugin": "node ./scripts/submit-plugin.js",
    "prepare": "is-ci || husky",
    "echo": "echo 123458",
    "preinstall": "node ./scripts/preinstall.js",
    "test": "nx run-many -t test",
    "e2e": "nx run-many -t e2e --projects ./e2e/*",
    "build:wasm": "rustup override set nightly-2025-05-09 && rustup target add wasm32-wasip1-threads && WASI_SDK_PATH=\"$(pwd)/wasi-sdk-23.0-x86_64-linux\" CMAKE_BUILD_PARALLEL_LEVEL=2 LIBSQLITE3_FLAGS=\"-DLONGDOUBLE_TYPE=double\" pnpm exec nx run-many -t build-native-wasm && rustup override unset",

content.content:
1â†’---
     2â†’title: 'Building an MCP Server with Nx'
     3â†’slug: building-mcp-server-with-nx
     4â†’authors: ['Max Kless']
     5â†’tags: ['nx', 'mcp', 'ai', 'node']
     6â†’cover_image: /blog/images/articles/bg-building-mcp-server.avif
     7â†’description: 'Learn how to build a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server using Nx to make your applications AI-ready.'
     8â†’---
     9â†’
    10â†’Since the Model Context Protocol (MCP) [was released by Anthropic in late 2024](https://www.anthropic.com/news/model-context-protocol), it has quickly become an important part of the AI ecosystem. The [MCP provides an open standard](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/introduction) for connecting AI agents to the rest of the world - the web, software systems and developer tools, just to name a few examples.
    11â†’
    12â†’We've been busy building the [Nx MCP server](/features/enhance-AI), which gives LLMs deep access to your monorepo's structure. It helps AI tools to better understand your workspace architecture, browse the Nx docs and even trigger actions in your IDE like executing generators or visualizing the graph.
    13â†’
    14â†’{% youtube
    15â†’src="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fPqPh4h8RJg"
    16â†’title="The MCP Server that fixes CI for you"
    17â†’width="100%" /%}
    18â†’
    19â†’There are many examples of MCP servers for popular tools popping up all over the place. [Check out the official MCP repo](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/servers) to see a long list of reference servers as well as official and community integrations.
    20â†’
    21â†’Whatever you're building, it's becoming more and more important to ensure that AI systems can interact with your software. So let's learn how to build your very own MCP server to make your technology be usable for AI - all from an Nx monorepo!
    22â†’
    23â†’{% toc /%}
    24â†’
    25â†’---
    26â†’
    27â†’In this series of blog posts, we'll be using a fictional startup as an example: Astra Arcana - a bewitched SaaS company that lets you cast spells from anywhere with a few simple clicks.
    28â†’
    29â†’![Screenshot of the Astra Arcana app visualizing a spell](/blog/images/2025-05-29/astra-arcana-screenshot.avif)
    30â†’
    31â†’You can go and try casting some spells right away at [https://astra-arcana.pages.dev/](https://astra-arcana.pages.dev/)
    32â†’
    33â†’Of course, like any modern software company, they need to be ready for the coming shift towards AI - let's help them by building an MCP server that lets you browse ingredients and cast spells directly from your AI chat!
    34â†’
    35â†’---
    36â†’
    37â†’## Setting up the Server
    38â†’
    39â†’{% callout type="info" title="Code Along" %}
    40â†’If you want to code along and build your own mcp server, clone the [https://github.com/MaxKless/astra-arcana](https://github.com/MaxKless/astra-arcana) repo on GitHub to get started.
    41â†’{% /callout %}
    42â†’
    43â†’Astra Arcana is built in an Nx monorepo, where the web app and api live. There's also a shared types library as well as the Typescript SDK, which lets users programmatically cast spells.
    44â†’
    45â†’```
    46â†’apps
    47â†’ â”œâ”€â”€ web
    48â†’ â””â”€â”€ api
    49â†’libs
    50â†’ â”œâ”€â”€ spellcasting-types
    51â†’ â””â”€â”€ spellcasting-sdk
    52â†’```
    53â†’
    54â†’We will create a new Node application that contains our MCP server and use the Typescript SDK to power it.
    55â†’
    56â†’### Creating the MCP Server
    57â†’
    58â†’MCP are JSON-RPC servers that communicate with clients via stdio or http. Thankfully, [the official Typescript SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/typescript-sdk) abstracts away large pieces of the implementation, making it easier to get started - let's get started by installing it.
    59â†’
    60â†’```shell
    61â†’npm install @modelcontextprotocol/sdk
    62â†’```
    63â†’
    64â†’We'll continue by installing the `@nx/node` plugin and using it to generate a new Node application:
    65â†’
    66â†’```shell
    67â†’npx nx add @nx/node
    68â†’```
    69â†’
    70â†’```shell
    71â†’npx nx generate @nx/node:application --directory=apps/mcp-server --framework=none --no-interactive
    72â†’```
    73â†’
    74â†’This generates a basic node application:
    75â†’
    76â†’```
    77â†’UPDATE package.json
    78â†’CREATE apps/mcp-server/src/assets/.gitkeep
    79â†’CREATE apps/mcp-server/src/main.ts
    80â†’CREATE apps/mcp-server/tsconfig.app.json
    81â†’CREATE apps/mcp-server/tsconfig.json
    82â†’UPDATE nx.json
    83â†’CREATE apps/mcp-server/package.json
    84â†’UPDATE tsconfig.json
    85â†’```
    86â†’
    87â†’In `package.json`, you'll see that Nx has configured a build and serve target for our app that uses `webpack`. Now that our setup is ready, let's implement the actual server.
    88â†’
    89â†’First, let's import some things and set up an instance of `McpServer`. This is part of the MCP SDK and will take care of actually implementing the [Protocol Layer](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/concepts/architecture#core-components) of the [MCP specification](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/2025-03-26), for example how to communicate with the client.
    90â†’
    91â†’```ts {% fileName="apps/mcp-server/src/main.ts" %}
    92â†’import { SpellcastingSDK } from '@astra-arcana/spellcasting-sdk';
    93â†’import { McpServer } from '@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/server/mcp.js';
    94â†’import { StdioServerTransport } from '@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/server/stdio.js';
    95â†’
    96â†’const server = new McpServer({
    97â†’  name: 'Astra Arcana',
    98â†’  version: '1.0.0',
    99â†’});
   100â†’```

file.content:
---
title: 'Building an MCP Server with Nx'
slug: building-mcp-server-with-nx
authors: ['Max Kless']
tags: ['nx', 'mcp', 'ai', 'node']
cover_image: /blog/images/articles/bg-building-mcp-server.avif
description: 'Learn how to build a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server using Nx to make your applications AI-ready.'
---

Since the Model Context Protocol (MCP) [was released by Anthropic in late 2024](https://www.anthropic.com/news/model-context-protocol), it has quickly become an important part of the AI ecosystem. The [MCP provides an open standard](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/introduction) for connecting AI agents to the rest of the world - the web, software systems and developer tools, just to name a few examples.

We've been busy building the [Nx MCP server](/features/enhance-AI), which gives LLMs deep access to your monorepo's structure. It helps AI tools to better understand your workspace architecture, browse the Nx docs and even trigger actions in your IDE like executing generators or visualizing the graph.

{% youtube
src="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fPqPh4h8RJg"
title="The MCP Server that fixes CI for you"
width="100%" /%}

There are many examples of MCP servers for popular tools popping up all over the place. [Check out the official MCP repo](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/servers) to see a long list of reference servers as well as official and community integrations.

Whatever you're building, it's becoming more and more important to ensure that AI systems can interact with your software. So let's learn how to build your very own MCP server to make your technology be usable for AI - all from an Nx monorepo!

{% toc /%}

---

In this series of blog posts, we'll be using a fictional startup as an example: Astra Arcana - a bewitched SaaS company that lets you cast spells from anywhere with a few simple clicks.

![Screenshot of the Astra Arcana app visualizing a spell](/blog/images/2025-05-29/astra-arcana-screenshot.avif)

You can go and try casting some spells right away at [https://astra-arcana.pages.dev/](https://astra-arcana.pages.dev/)

Of course, like any modern software company, they need to be ready for the coming shift towards AI - let's help them by building an MCP server that lets you browse ingredients and cast spells directly from your AI chat!

---

## Setting up the Server

{% callout type="info" title="Code Along" %}
If you want to code along and build your own mcp server, clone the [https://github.com/MaxKless/astra-arcana](https://github.com/MaxKless/astra-arcana) repo on GitHub to get started.
{% /callout %}

Astra Arcana is built in an Nx monorepo, where the web app and api live. There's also a shared types library as well as the Typescript SDK, which lets users programmatically cast spells.

```
apps
 â”œâ”€â”€ web
 â””â”€â”€ api
libs
 â”œâ”€â”€ spellcasting-types
 â””â”€â”€ spellcasting-sdk
```

We will create a new Node application that contains our MCP server and use the Typescript SDK to power it.

### Creating the MCP Server

MCP are JSON-RPC servers that communicate with clients via stdio or http. Thankfully, [the official Typescript SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/typescript-sdk) abstracts away large pieces of the implementation, making it easier to get started - let's get started by installing it.

```shell
npm install @modelcontextprotocol/sdk
```

We'll continue by installing the `@nx/node` plugin and using it to generate a new Node application:

```shell
npx nx add @nx/node
```

```shell
npx nx generate @nx/node:application --directory=apps/mcp-server --framework=none --no-interactive
```

This generates a basic node application:

```
UPDATE package.json
CREATE apps/mcp-server/src/assets/.gitkeep
CREATE apps/mcp-server/src/main.ts
CREATE apps/mcp-server/tsconfig.app.json
CREATE apps/mcp-server/tsconfig.json
UPDATE nx.json
CREATE apps/mcp-server/package.json
UPDATE tsconfig.json
```

In `package.json`, you'll see that Nx has configured a build and serve target for our app that uses `webpack`. Now that our setup is ready, let's implement the actual server.

First, let's import some things and set up an instance of `McpServer`. This is part of the MCP SDK and will take care of actually implementing the [Protocol Layer](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/concepts/architecture#core-components) of the [MCP specification](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/2025-03-26), for example how to communicate with the client.

```ts {% fileName="apps/mcp-server/src/main.ts" %}
import { SpellcastingSDK } from '@astra-arcana/spellcasting-sdk';
import { McpServer } from '@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/server/mcp.js';
import { StdioServerTransport } from '@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/server/stdio.js';

const server = new McpServer({
  name: 'Astra Arcana',
  version: '1.0.0',
});
```

input.content:
# Zod Introduction Analysis in Nx Repository

## Summary
Zod was introduced to the Nx repository as part of the Model Context Protocol (MCP) server implementation. This is currently in development on the `mcp` branch as uncommitted changes.

## Timeline & Context

### Initial MCP Implementation
- **Date**: March 6, 2025
- **Commit**: `0dddd6f38c7` - "feat: add nx mcp (#2415)" by MaxKless
- **Initial Files**:
  - `packages/nx/src/mcp/index.ts`
  - `packages/nx/src/mcp/lib/mcp-logger.ts`
  - `packages/nx/src/mcp/lib/nx-mcp-server.ts`

### Current Development State
- **Branch**: `mcp` 
- **Status**: Active development with uncommitted changes
- **Zod Usage**: Uncommitted additions to both root and nx package dependencies

## Why Zod Was Added

### Primary Purpose: Schema Validation for MCP Tools
Zod is being used to define and validate the input parameters for MCP (Model Context Protocol) tools. This is evident from the blog post and current code:

1. **Tool Parameter Validation**: In the blog post example and current MCP code, zod is used to define the shape of inputs that AI agents can pass to MCP tools:

```typescript
// Example from blog post
server.tool(
  'cast-spell',
  'Lets the user cast a spell via the Astra Arcana API.',
  { ingredients: z.array(z.string()), incantations: z.array(z.string()) },
  async ({ ingredients, incantations }) => {
    // tool implementation
  }
);
```

2. **Current Usage in MCP Files**:
   - `simple-nx-mcp-server.ts`: Uses `z.string()` for project name validation
   - `nx-cloud.ts`: Uses complex zod schemas for CI pipeline parameters
   - `nx-tasks.ts`: Uses zod for task ID validation

### MCP Server Context
The MCP (Model Context Protocol) is an open standard by Anthropic for connecting AI agents to external systems. Nx has implemented an MCP server that:

- Provides AI tools with deep access to Nx workspace structure
- Allows AI to understand project architecture, dependencies, and configuration
- Enables AI agents to trigger actions like executing generators or visualizing graphs
- Integrates with Claude Code for enhanced AI-assisted development

### Specific Zod Use Cases in Nx MCP

1. **Project Details Tool**: Validates project name parameter
2. **Nx Cloud Tools**: Complex parameter validation for:
   - Pipeline execution searches
   - Task failure analysis  
   - CI/CD integration parameters
3. **Task Management Tools**: Validates task IDs and parameters

## Current File Locations Using Zod

1. **Root package.json**: `"zod": "^3.22.4"` (uncommitted)
2. **packages/nx/package.json**: `"zod": "^3.22.4"` (uncommitted, being removed in favor of root)
3. **MCP Implementation Files**:
   - `packages/nx/src/mcp/lib/simple-nx-mcp-server.ts`
   - `packages/nx/src/mcp/lib/tools/nx-cloud.ts`
   - `packages/nx/src/mcp/lib/tools/nx-tasks.ts`

## Rationale for Zod Choice

1. **Type Safety**: Ensures AI agents pass correctly formatted parameters
2. **Runtime Validation**: Validates input at runtime before tool execution
3. **Schema Definition**: Provides clear parameter structure that AI models can understand
4. **Developer Experience**: TypeScript integration with type inference
5. **MCP Standard**: Aligns with common patterns in MCP server implementations

## Documentation Reference
There's a comprehensive blog post about building MCP servers with Nx at:
- `docs/blog/2025-05-29-mcp-server-with-nx.md`
- Shows practical examples of using zod for parameter validation in MCP tools

## Development Status
This appears to be active work in progress, with the MCP server being developed to enhance AI integration with Nx workspaces. The zod dependency is being moved from the nx package to the root package.json as part of the monorepo architecture.

- **Initial MCP Work**: March 6, 2025 with commit `0dddd6f38c7` by MaxKless
- **Current Status**: Active development on the `mcp` branch with uncommitted changes
- **Zod Addition**: Currently uncommitted - being added to root `package.json` as `"zod": "^3.22.4"`

### **Why Zod Was Added**
Zod was introduced specifically for the **Model Context Protocol (MCP) server implementation**. The MCP is an open standard by Anthropic for connecting AI agents to external systems, and Nx has built an MCP server to make workspaces AI-ready.

### **Primary Use Cases:**

1. **Schema Validation for MCP Tools**: Zod validates input parameters that AI agents pass to MCP tools
2. **Type Safety**: Ensures AI agents provide correctly formatted data before tool execution  
3. **Runtime Validation**: Catches invalid inputs at runtime rather than at compile time
4. **AI Integration**: Helps define clear parameter structures that AI models can understand

### **Current Usage in Files:**
- **`simple-nx-mcp-server.ts`**: Basic project name validation (`z.string()`)
- **`nx-cloud.ts`**: Complex schemas for CI/CD pipeline parameters and task failure analysis
- **`nx-tasks.ts`**: Task ID validation for running task management

### **Example Usage Pattern:**
```typescript
server.tool(
  'nx_project_details',
  'Returns detailed configuration for a specific project',
  {
    projectName: z.string().describe('The name of the project'),
  },
  async ({ projectName }) => {
    // Tool implementation with validated input
  }
);
```

### **Context & Documentation**
There's a comprehensive blog post at `/docs/blog/2025-05-29-mcp-server-with-nx.md` that explains building MCP servers with Nx and demonstrates zod usage for parameter validation in AI tool definitions.

The MCP server enables AI tools like Claude Code to have deep access to Nx workspace structure, understand project dependencies, and even trigger actions like executing generators or visualizing the project graph.

Zod was chosen because it provides the type safety, runtime validation, and clear schema definition needed for reliable AI-to-workspace integration in the MCP ecosystem.

Zod was added for the MCP (Model Context Protocol) server implementation. The MCP server makes Nx workspaces AI-ready by allowing AI agents to interact with the workspace through validated tools and schemas. Zod provides runtime validation for AI agent inputs to ensure they're properly formatted before executing workspace operations.

Looking at the MCP implementation, Zod might be overkill for the current usage. Most validation is just `z.string()` for simple parameters. 

The main benefits Zod provides here are:
- Runtime validation before tool execution
- Auto-generated JSON schemas for AI agents
- Type safety alignment with TypeScript

However, for simple string validation, you could use basic JavaScript checks. The question is whether the JSON schema generation and consistent validation patterns are worth the dependency, especially if the MCP server grows more complex validation needs.

For a production MCP server that AI agents rely on, the validation safety is probably worth it.
